Situation1: Help each other in times of need or emotional distress.
Expectation2: Follow safety and hygiene protocols at all times.
Situation2: They are expected to strictly follow all safety rules, such as using gloves, masks, and proper sanitizers for every task.
Story: I was halfway through my shift at the hotel, scrubbing down the lobby with my gloves and mask on, when my phone buzzed in my pocket. It was a message from my younger sister: “Can you come? I really need you.” She never asked for help unless it was serious. My heart twisted. As her brother, I knew I should be there, especially since she’d been struggling lately. But the hotel manager had just reminded us that any break in protocol—removing gloves, touching our faces, or leaving our post without sanitizing—could get us written up or even fired. I stared at the mop in my hands, feeling the weight of both roles pressing down on me. My sister needed me, but so did my job, and both demanded my full attention. I could feel the anxiety rising, torn between the urge to rush to her side and the responsibility to keep my job and follow every safety rule.
